title: Implement error propagation for CF-LIBS
description: Uncertainties in atomic data (A_ki 10-50%) and measurements propagate to T, ne, concentrations. Users need realistic error bars.
design:
1. Analytical: Covariance matrix from linear regression -> σ_T
2. Monte Carlo: Perturb inputs (I±σ_I, A_ki±σ_A), re-run solver 100x
3. Report: T±σ_T, ne±σ_ne, C±σ_C for each element
4. Correlation matrix between parameters
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Analytical errors match Monte Carlo for simple cases
- [ ] Monte Carlo captures non-linear effects
- [ ] Error bars reported in standard output
- [ ] Correlation information available

title: Implement round-trip testing framework
description: Validate inversion by generating synthetic spectra with known parameters, adding noise, then inverting. Critical for ensuring inversion accuracy.
design:
1. Generate Golden Spectra with fixed seeds and known (T, ne, composition)
2. Noise model: Poisson (shot) + Gaussian (readout)
3. Run inversion on noisy spectra
4. Verify parameter recovery: T±5%, ne±20%, C±10%
5. CI integration for regression testing
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Golden spectra reproducible (fixed seeds)
- [ ] Noise model realistic
- [ ] Parameter recovery within tolerances
- [ ] Automated in CI pipeline

title: Implement iterative CF-LIBS solver
description: Core algorithm: iterative relaxation solver that self-consistently determines T, ne, and concentrations. U(T) and ne depend on T, creating circular dependencies that require iteration.
design:
Algorithm:
1. Initialize T0=10000K, ne0=1e17 cm-3
2. Calculate U(T) for all species
3. Correct ionic lines to neutral Boltzmann plane
4. Weighted linear regression for T
5. Extract species intercepts -> concentrations
6. Apply closure equation (ΣC=1)
7. Update ne via Saha
8. Iterate until ΔT < ε
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Converges in <20 iterations for typical conditions
- [ ] T, ne match literature values for benchmark spectra
- [ ] Concentrations sum to 1.0 after closure
- [ ] Handles multiple elements simultaneously

title: Implement Stark broadening
description: Stark broadening is the PRIMARY diagnostic for electron density in LIBS. Without it, ne determination is impossible. Current code has no Stark implementation.
design:
1. Stark width scaling law: w(n_e, T) = w_ref * (n_e/10^16) * (T/T_ref)^(-0.5)
2. Database lookup for w_ref, alpha parameters
3. Fallback approximation for lines missing Stark data (derive from upper energy level)
4. Optional Stark shift for asymmetric profiles
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Stark width calculation matches literature values
- [ ] Fallback approximation works for missing data
- [ ] Integrated with line profile calculations
- [ ] Can determine ne from measured line widths

title: Implement self-absorption correction
description: CF-LIBS is notorious for self-absorption errors in optically thick plasmas. Strong lines (especially resonance lines) can be optically thick, causing intensity underestimation.
design:
Primary method: Recursive correction
1. Calculate optical depth τ0 using current n_s, T
2. Correction factor f = (1 - exp(-τ)) / τ
3. I_corrected = I_measured / f
4. Iterate with main solver

Fallback: Simply mask lines with τ0 > threshold
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Recursive correction converges
- [ ] Reduces systematic concentration errors
- [ ] Can mask heavily absorbed lines
- [ ] Optical depth estimates reasonable

title: Implement hybrid inversion strategy

design: Step 1: Coarse Search - manifold nearest neighbor (cosine similarity) -> initial guess T0, ne0\nStep 2: Fine Tune - JAX autodiff + BFGS/L-M optimizer starting from coarse guess\nBenefit: Avoids local minima while achieving high precision
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Coarse search finds reasonable starting point
- [ ] Gradient descent converges from coarse guess
- [ ] Faster than pure optimization
- [ ] More robust than pure manifold lookup

title: Implement closure equation with multiple modes
description: The closure equation ΣC=1 is what makes calibration-free analysis possible. It eliminates the unknown experimental factor F. Must handle invisible elements (O, N, C).
design:
Modes:
1. Standard: ΣC_measured = 1.0
2. Matrix mode: ΣC_measured + C_matrix = 1.0 (user specifies balance element)
3. Stoichiometric oxide mode: cations map to oxides (e.g., Al->Al2O3), closure on oxides
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Standard mode works for simple alloys
- [ ] Matrix mode handles Fe-dominated samples
- [ ] Oxide mode works for geological samples
- [ ] Warning when measured elements < 50% of total
